Key provision: If onset is clear and < 48 hr, Pharmacologic or electrical cardioversion is safe.

agreements.source_filename: Service agreements/Kaiser Bariatric Surgery CT Scan Protocols.docx
summary_bullets: Workflow detail: The protocol for CT scanning patients after bariatric surgery falls into two basic groups.
Workflow detail: CT Tech > CT Scout Chest/Abdomen/Pelvis, with the chest portion being an actual PE protocol.
Key provision: Early Postop: Within the first 30 days after surgery, when the patient cannot drink much and the suspicion for leak and PE are highest.
Key provision: Provide 100 mL oral contrast and have the patient consume it over one hour.
Key provision: CT Tech > Protocol set-up PE Protocol, then at 70 sec. post-iv injection, scan routine Abd/Pelvis.
Key provision: Late Postop: More than 30 days after surgery.
Key provision: Provide the usual volume of oral contrast, and allow a full 3 hours to consume it.

agreements.title: Psych and ED Service Agreement
agreements.source_filename: Service agreements/Psych and ED Service Agreement.docx
summary_bullets: Agreement purpose: This purpose of this agreement is to outline the coordination of services provided by the Emergency and Psychiatry Departments in the treatment and disposition of psychiatric.
Scope focus: Medical and psychiatric treatment of suspected psychiatric patients will begin immediately by the ED team per usual department protocols.
Scope focus: A Psychiatrist will be available at all times for a telephone consult during medical clearance for questions regarding psychiatric medications.
Workflow detail: This document serves to identify the minimum baseline service level and should be supplemented by local operational policies and clinical protocols.

Clinical criteria: Medication management consultations by Psychiatry should be requested in cases where symptoms are present. These may include, but are not limited to, severe anxiety, severe depression.

Clinical criteria: “Psych Treatment Team” – refers to the local area specific Psychiatry providers who cover the Emergency Department. This could include Psychiatrists, Therapists, Case Managers, Nurses, and.
Escalation note: After hours, the on call Psych Treatment Team/PET will be available for consultation.
Escalation note: The attending ED Physician and consulting Psychiatrist should follow a local escalation process to notify the ED Chief and Psych Chief or Behavioral Health Quality Management.
Disposition/ownership: The ED Treatment Team (or CDU Provider) will sign out medical care of psychiatric patients to the next ED Treatment Team (or CDU Provider) at the.
Disposition/ownership: Psychotropic medications dispensed upon discharge should be provided with rapid internal follow up or referral to community mental health if the patient is not a KP.
ed_actions: ED action: Medical and psychiatric treatment of suspected psychiatric patients will begin immediately by the ED team per usual department protocols.
ED action: The ED Treatment Team (or CDU Provider) will sign out medical care of psychiatric patients to the next ED Treatment Team (or CDU Provider).
ED action: The ED Physician, Psych Treatment Team, and Security officers and supervisors will work in collaboration to ensure sufficient coverage for patient care and department.
ED action: For geriatric psych, dementia, and Alzheimer’s patients, the ED Physician and Psych Treatment Team will engage ED case management and social medicine to identify.
ED action: The ED treatment team or ED case manager will update the Psych Treatment Team daily of patients in need of new consults or rounding.
ED should: This document serves to identify the minimum baseline service level and should be supplemented by local operational policies and clinical protocols.
ED should: The ED physicians will order labs as needed per local/county facility requirements when they feel the patient will most likely be admitted to a.
ED should: After hours, the on call Psych Treatment Team/PET will be available for consultation.
consults_and_escalation: Consult flow: A Psychiatrist will be available at all times for a telephone consult during medical clearance for questions regarding psychiatric medications.
Consult flow: If a patient is acutely intoxicated from alcohol/drugs and does not have the capacity to undergo a psychiatric assessment, a psych consult can be.
Consult flow: Consistent with other local area specialty consultation agreements, ideally, a face to face assessment by the Psych Treatment Team/PET should be performed within 2-4.
Consult flow: During daytime hours, the on duty Psychiatrist will be available for consult.
Consult flow: After hours, the on call Psych Treatment Team/PET will be available for consultation.
Escalation: The attending ED Physician and consulting Psychiatrist should follow a local escalation process to notify the ED Chief and Psych Chief or Behavioral Health.
Escalation: “ED Physician” – refers to the attending emergency department physician.
Escalation: Regional Coordinating Chief, Emergency Medicine.
disposition_or_ownership: Ownership/disposition: This purpose of this agreement is to outline the coordination of services provided by the Emergency and Psychiatry Departments in the treatment and disposition.
Ownership/disposition: The ED Treatment Team (or CDU Provider) will sign out medical care of psychiatric patients to the next ED Treatment Team (or CDU Provider).
Ownership/disposition: Patients discharged to home may be given a prescription for no more than 7 days of psychiatric medication until medication management can be assumed.

agreements.title: Urology and Emergency Medicine Service Agreement 2019
agreements.source_filename: Service agreements/Urology and Emergency Medicine Service Agreement 2019.docx
summary_bullets: Disposition/ownership: Hospital Medicine admit and no need to call Urologic Surgery overnight (7 pm- 7am).
Key pathway point: Obstructive ureteral stone with fever (>38C).
Key provision: Acute epididymo-orchitis with sepsis and no abscess or gangrene.
Key provision: Fournier's gangrene of scrotum and penis (if perirectal involvement or not sure, call general surgery).
Key provision: No need to call Urologist and out-patient Urologic Surgery referral.
Key provision: No Urologic Surgery referral and follow-up with PCP.
Key provision: Difficult catheterization in acute urinary retention.

summary_bullets: Agreement purpose: In order to provide consistent support to the Emergency Department, the Department of Urology has provided a list of common urological pathologies seen in the ED.
Key pathway point: Obstructive urinary stone with fever (>38C) or intractable pain or intractable vomiting.
Key provision: Fournier's gangrene of scrotum and penis (if perirectal involvement or not sure, call general surgery).
Key provision: Urological Evaluation of Emergency Department Patients.
Key provision: Difficult catheterization and acute post-op surgical complications.
Key provision: Acute urinary retention s/p Foley placement.
Key provision: No Urology referral and followup with PCP.
